captions.text:
A lot of games these days start with the story or 
theme and pick the gameplay elements off the peg,

as it were. A nice coat of open world. 
A sweater of stealth action. Large,

unflattering underpants of crafting bearing 
the skidmarks of like fifteen previous wearers,

Personally the games I find more interesting 
are the ones that started by coming up with some

unique gameplay element and then tailored a story 
and setting around that. Pokemon would be a good

example. The game set in a society that almost 
completely revolves around cockfighting. To the

point that even the nurses have trained fighting 
roosters as personal assistants. Which would be

like if in the UK footballers were employed at 
every level of society, like they hire a few to

hang around hospital corridors kicking donated 
organs into operating rooms. And then there&#39;s

this week&#39;s subject, Lost in Random, a game that 
clearly started with a combat system based around

combining random dice rolls with deckbuilding and 
realtime combat along some Hand-of-Fate-y sorts of

lines and then had to contrive a setting and story 
entirely based around that. For a start, it takes

place in the land of Random. As in, that&#39;s 
literally what it&#39;s called. Fucking hell,

even Pokemon isn&#39;t flat out set in Wounded 
Poultry Topia. In the distant past of Random,

everyone had a dice and all conflict was resolved 
in dice battles where warriors threw dice to score

points and spent the points to use the cards in 
their hand to make weapons manifest. We aren&#39;t

told how this whole arrangement came about, seems 
like a lot of middlemen could&#39;ve been cut out of

this process. What&#39;s wrong with just twatting each 
other with sticks? Or how about this - twat each

other with the dice? Line the corner up right, 
you could probably gouge an eye out. Anyway,

this all changed when an evil queen arrived and 
destroyed everyone&#39;s dice except her own, with

which she now rules over all of Random, decreeing 
that whenever a child comes of age they must be

taken away from their families and forced to live 
in whichever of the six conveniently numbered

cities her dice decrees. The story focusses on Odd 
and Even, two young sisters who are lowly peasants

living in One-town, or Oners, as they&#39;re known 
- I&#39;d have gone with Onekers, myself. After Odd

rolls a six and is taken away by the Queen&#39;s 
minions Even vows to journey across the land

to rescue her from her new position of wealth and 
high status and resume their happy carefree lives

in the sewer where they belong. On the way she 
joins forces with the last of the magical dice,

allowing her to fight back against the Queen&#39;s 
army of robot enforcers by mastering the art of

random fighting. And not in the sense of the 
thing I always do when forced to play Mortal

Kombat. This is probably one of those reviews 
where all the comments will be like &quot;Urgh why are

you playing this game I personally haven&#39;t heard 
of instead of the latest instalment of Broody

Anime Sword Boy And The Hottie He Persistently 
Fails To Snog Adventures,&quot; but you should know

by now that I&#39;m attracted to quirkiness, and Lost 
in Random has a lot of that very specific Tim

Burton-y American McGee&#39;s Alice-y flavour of quirk 
where the environment designers have never heard

of a straight line, and all the characters look 
like factory reject plushies made from stitched

together discarded fish carcasses. Actually if 
I were to summarise Lost in Random&#39;s theming

I&#39;d go for &quot;It&#39;s American McGee&#39;s Alice if Lewis 
Carroll&#39;s estate sent the frighteners round and

told them they had to take out all the references 
to Alice in Wonderland. And then another set

of frighteners from Isaac Newton&#39;s estate came 
round and told them it couldn&#39;t have any jumping,

either.&quot; It does feel weird that the game doesn&#39;t 
have a jump button. Yeah, Even&#39;s got pipe cleaners

for legs but that never stopped Sonic the 
Hedgehog. And the lack of vertical movement

hamstrings a lot of the environment into corridor 
mazes which no amount of trapezoidal doorways can

make terribly interesting. Nor indeed can a 
terribly quirky artisanal map screen that&#39;s

absolutely bloody useless for actually figuring 
out how to get to places. On a similar note,

while there&#39;s a lot of creativity in character 
design, the characters don&#39;t do much. So you&#39;ll

have a dude with four eyes and a head shaped like 
a Chesterfield sofa and another that looks like a

character from Spongebob Squarepants recreated 
in decaying chicken skin and they&#39;re all just

standing around waiting for you to talk to them so 
they can send you on one of the suffocating wastes

of time they call sidequests, which generally 
entail going out of your way to talk to another

weirdo across town then report back on what 
they said. Then you get rewarded with a card

you&#39;ve already got and don&#39;t use much anyway. 
Unrewarding? Lack of movement options? Hard to

understand map? Bunch of weirdos standing around? 
What is this, the San Francisco bus system? So in

gameplay terms at least Lost In Random has gone 
all in on the combat system. How that works is,

you build yourself a deck of cards you&#39;ve 
collected, then when you&#39;re in the combat

arena you use your harmless slingshot weapon to 
burst a few of the enemy&#39;s protruding blackheads

until you can gather enough magic pus to draw 
a few cards, then you roll the dice to get a

number of points that you can then spend 
on activating the cards. So you activate a

big twatting stick card to equip yourself with a 
twatting stick with which to twat the enemy. Yeah,

I know it sounds like an awful lot of unnecessary 
steps in the way of twatting things with sticks,

but it&#39;s having to deal with the random element 
that adds the extra spice, isn&#39;t it. Maybe you

needed to spend the points on healing this round. 
Maybe you didn&#39;t have enough points for the

twatting stick and had to go back to bursting zits 
for a few minutes or make do with the castigating

tube. Maybe you didn&#39;t draw a twatting stick 
card this round so you have to lay down a trap

or that one that makes your dice friend explode 
after nine seconds. Bitch, I don&#39;t know where

the fuck I&#39;m going to be in nine seconds. I&#39;ve 
lost control of my life. Or maybe you&#39;ll draw

the card that shoots a laser as powerful as a 
stream of cold piss between you and your dice

friend that you might be able to politely ask the 
enemies to stand in the way of if you&#39;re lucky.

Or maybe you won&#39;t because you didn&#39;t put that 
card in your deck because you&#39;re not a fucking

dunce. Hybrids of turn based and live action 
combat rarely turn out for the best. In this case,

all that really manners is damaging the enemy, no 
method they give you is more efficient than a big

twatting stick, or some explosive arrows, and 
while you&#39;re waiting for one of those to come

up you can just dodge all the enemy attacks. It&#39;s 
not exactly strategic. And you can tell they were

struggling to come up with ideas for cards because 
there&#39;s only about thirty and a lot of them are

useless and by the end of the game the fucking 
card merchant literally bellend on the kitchen

worktop ran out of cards to sell me, and then 
whoops, in-game money and everything I could do to

get it suddenly had no purpose. But I don&#39;t hate 
Lost in Random, there was creativity on display,

the story hits in the right places, and it was, 
after all, an experiment, and that&#39;s laudable.

Experiments are how we learn. This particular mix 
of injections made the guinea pig&#39;s brain die off.

No worries. Chalk it up, bring in a new guinea 
pig. What do you mean, get out of my pet shop?
